Award.AwardTitle: STARSS: Small: SecureDust -- The Physical Limits of Information Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Truly ubiquitous computing with very small, self-powered and wirelessly networked integrated circuits will become possible within a decade. Applications of these devices include biosensors, environmental monitors, and defense, all of which bring a need for security and privacy. Enabling the use of strong cryptographic algorithms on extremely constrained devices requires rethinking, from an energy-first perspective, the design and implementation of basic cryptographic building blocks. The Secure Dust project seeks to reduce the energy of cryptographic functions in advanced technologies by an order of magnitude, and to validate the designs using test chips. The findings of this project will help to secure future ubiquitous devices and the Internet of Things.

The specific research objective of this project is to explore the scaling down of security functions into advanced CMOS technologies and in particular the important role of manufacturing variations and noise that can be both advantageous (Physical Unclonable Functions and Random Number Generation) and detrimental (side-channel resistant ciphers and hash functions) depending on the cryptography block. We target an energy budget of picojoules per secure transaction, built upon basic cryptography functions. The project combines design expertise in lightweight cryptography using block ciphers, hash functions, PUFs and RNGs, along with low-energy techniques and realistic semiconductor design flows and economic realities. FPGA-prototyping and CMOS FinFET test chips will be used to demonstrate complete cryptosystem functionality, including side-channel susceptibility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Truly ubiquitous computing with very small, self-powered and wirelessly networked integrated circuits will become possible within a decade. Applications of these devices include biosensors, environmental monitors, and defense, all of which bring a need for security and privacy. This project aims to support these applications by enabling the use of strong cryptographic algorithms on extremely constrained devices, which requires rethinking the design and implementation of basic cryptographic building blocks to improve energy efficiency and resist attacks.

The research conducted in this project advances the state of security for lightweight hardware in several ways. A primary outcome is our hardware implementation of the AES encryption algorithm. Our design uses a register renaming approach to minimize energy-inefficient data movement. We implemented this design on a VLSI testchip in 16nm FinFET technology, and then evaluated its efficiency and side-channel susceptibility in our laboratory. The design surpasses the energy efficiency of comparable pre-existing AES implementations and is able to encrypt data at an energy cost of 0.55pJ per bit at nominal supply voltage.

A second significant contribution of the project is exploring susceptibility of VLSI circuits to various attacks, and then proposing countermeasures to help secure the circuits against the attacks. This part of the research spans VLSI implementations on both application specific integrated circuits, and field programmable gate arrays. We have particularly explored information leaked through data-dependent power consumption and proximate wire coupling in VLSI circuits, as well as fault injection through targeted manipulation of supply voltage. For highly constrained hardware, we've aimed to develop cost-effective mitigation strategies against the attacks. The intellectual contributions of the research have led to a best paper award, a best poster award, and a departmental dissertation award for our students.

In addition to the intellectual contributions, the project has impacted education. The research has significantly supported the research at UMass Amherst of four Undergraduate, four Masters, and three Ph.D. students. These students have transitioned their knowledge into the US workforce in jobs spanning cybersecurity and the semiconductor industry. Notably, the four undergraduate students all co-authored research papers from this research. The research from this project has also made a strong educational impact by producing material used by existing classes, and was instrumental in the creation of a new undergraduate cybersecurity class at UMass that is now and henceforth taken by all computer engineering students during their junior year.
